edu.berkeley.compbio.sequtils

Class SequenceFragmentMetadata<C extends SequenceFragmentMetadata>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.davidsoergel.dsutils.LabellableImpl<String>
      • edu.berkeley.compbio.sequtils.SequenceFragmentMetadata<C>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    com.davidsoergel.dsutils.Labellable<String>, Serializable, Comparable<C>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SequenceFragment

    public class SequenceFragmentMetadata<C extends SequenceFragmentMetadata>
extends com.davidsoergel.dsutils.LabellableImpl<String>
implements Comparable<C>, Serializable
    Provides a container for information about a particular sequence. Sequence fragments are related hierarchically by containment; a larger fragment containing this one is called its "parent". For instance, a given FASTA file may contain many different sequences. In this case a SequenceFragmentMetadata representing the file as a whole is the parent of the SequenceFragmentMetadatas representing each individual sequence.

    While a SequenceFragmentMetadata may consist of unconnected sequences (e.g., chromosomes), it assumes these are contiguous, and in a consistent order, for the sake of sequence coordinates.

    Version:
    $Id$
    Author:
    David Soergel

      • length

        protected long length
        The total number of characters represented by this fragment, including "N" characters or whatever. May have the value UNKNOWN_LENGTH if the fragment has not yet been scanned.

    • Constructor Detail

      • SequenceFragmentMetadata

        public SequenceFragmentMetadata(SequenceFragmentMetadata parent,
                        String sequenceName,
                        Integer taxid,
                        int startPosition)
        Constructs a new SequenceFragmentMetadata by specifying its start position with respect to a containing parent sequence, but with an unknown length. (The length will presumably be determined and set later, as needed.)
        Parameters:
        parent - the SequenceFragmentMetadata representing a larger sequence in which this one is contained
        sequenceName - a String identifier for this sequence
        startPosition - the index in the parent sequence of the first symbol in this sequence

      • SequenceFragmentMetadata

        Parameters:

        sequenceName - a String identifier for this sequence
        startPosition - the index in the parent sequence of the first symbol in this sequence
        length - the length of this sequence

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(C o)
        Compares this object with the specified object for order. Returns a negative integer, zero, or a positive integer as this object is less than, equal to, or greater than the specified object.

        The implementor must ensure sgn(x.compareTo(y)) == -sgn(y.compareTo(x)) for all x and y. (This implies that x.compareTo(y) must throw an exception iff y.compareTo(x) throws an exception.)

        The implementor must also ensure that the relation is transitive: (x.compareTo(y)>0 && y.compareTo(z)>0) implies x.compareTo(z)>0.

        Finally, the implementor must ensure that x.compareTo(y)==0 implies that sgn(x.compareTo(z)) == sgn(y.compareTo(z)), for all z.

        It is strongly recommended, but not strictly required that (x.compareTo(y)==0) == (x.equals(y)). Generally speaking, any class that implements the Comparable interface and violates this condition should clearly indicate this fact. The recommended language is "Note: this class has a natural ordering that is inconsistent with equals."

        In the foregoing description, the notation sgn(expression) designates the mathematical signum function, which is defined to return one of -1, 0, or 1 according to whether the value of expression is negative, zero or positive.

        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface Comparable<C extends SequenceFragmentMetadata>
        Parameters:
        o - the object to be compared.
        Returns:
        a negative integer, zero, or a positive integer as this object is less than, equal to, or greater than the specified object.
        Throws:
        ClassCastException - if the specified object's type prevents it from being compared to this object.
